1 JANUARY.part3: VERSE 1 Paul puts it this way: God the Father chose us in
1 JANUARY.part7: There is therefore now no condemnation to them which are in Christ Jesus, who walk not after the flesh, but after the Spirit.  THOUGHT  alvation is the work of God, not ours. There is no condemnation because of what the triune God has done. In theology, this is known as the covenant of redemption, referring to the harmony and unity of purpose in the Trinity before the foundation of the world on the matter of salvation. God the Father, God the Son and God the Holy Spirit are in complete agreement for all eternity in terms of bringing forth the work of redemption. Paul puts it this way: God the Father chose us in Christ Jesus (God the Son) and we are sealed with the "Holy Spirit of promise" (read Ephesians 1:2- 14). What is the role of God the Father in the work of redemption? He sent the Son in the likeness of sinful man to be the sin offering; and in so doing, God not only condemned sin in the flesh, but His demands for perfect righteousness are also fully satisfied in those who are united to Christ [2 Corinthians 5:21]. What is the role of God the Son? Christ did the work of redemption. He came to "give His life a ransom for many" [Mark 10:45]. Christ was "the Lamb of God, which taketh away the sin of the world" [John 1:29]. He was "the propitiation for our sins" [1 John 2:2], appeasing the righteous wrath of a holy God. What is the role of the Holy Spirit? He joins us to Christ. We are in Christ by the Holy Spirit. Paul tells us that Christians are "sealed with that holy Spirit of promise, which is the earnest of our inheritance until the redemption of the purchased possession" [Ephesians 1:13-14]. Being thus joined, we can be certain there is "therefore now no condemnation to them which are in Christ Jesus". All praise to the triune God whose work of redemption gives us abundant life forever.

2 JANUARY.part3: VERSE 1 When Paul says there is now no condemnation
2 JANUARY.part7: There is therefore now no condemnation to them which are in Christ Jesus, who walk not after the flesh, but after the Spirit.  THOUGHT  he apostle Paul has been telling us that before God, we are all guilty and liable for His wrath and punishment. The Jews thought they could escape this because they had the law. They prided themselves in knowing God's commandments, but Paul pointed out the law just made them less excusable because "by the deeds of the law there shall no flesh be justified in (God's) sight" [Romans 3:20]. When Paul says there is now no condemnation for those who are in Christ, it is not due to the suspension or annulment of the law; rather it is a vicarious provision being made on our behalf. One writer calls it the objective provision of the Gospel of Christ. It is objective because our condemnation has been absolved not because God closed His eyes to sin but because our sins have been paid in full by Christ's work on our behalf. The Son of God endured the wrath of God in our place on the accursed tree. The word "condemnation" in Romans 8:1 has a prefix intensifying its meaning of total and final condemnation. But because of the totality and finality of the atoning sacrifice by our Lord Jesus Christ, the dreadful condemnation has been totally and completely removed. What is amazing is that this is a fact at this present moment. There is "now no condemnation to them which are in Christ Jesus". This is not just a future hope, but it is also a present reality. We know the day will come when we have to give an account before God. That day, we will stand confident in Christ because even now, there is already no condemnation. "He that believeth on the Son hath everlasting life: and he that believeth not the Son shall not see life; but the wrath of God abideth on him" [John 3:36]. Are you in Christ?

3 JANUARY.part7: There is therefore now no condemnation to them which are in Christ Jesus, who walk not after the flesh, but after the Spirit.  THOUGHT  he Christian's walk is our manner of living. It is what our life is all about. Our "walk" is our way of life. Our walk is identified by what we live for and what motivates us. It is identified by the things with which and people with whom we associate. It is identified by where the affections of our hearts lie. It is identified by what comes out of our hearts by way of our mouths. It is identified by the place and authority we give to Christ in our lives. Walking after the flesh is having our lives completely directed by and carried away with our carnal desires and carnal minds. It has been said that some people eat to live, while others live to eat. When food becomes the dominating and controlling factor in one's life, one is walking after the flesh. When your purpose in life is only to satisfy carnal desires (food, pleasure, entertainment, etc.), you are walking after the flesh. God has given us "richly all things to enjoy" [1 Timothy 6:17], but when we start to live for those things so that they crowd out the more important things in life, we are walking after the flesh. Our walk is either after the flesh or after the Spirit. It cannot be both because they are diametrically opposed. "The flesh lusteth against the Spirit, and the Spirit against the flesh: and these are contrary the one to the other" [Galatians 5:17]. We cannot do both at the same time. The inward transformation of our nature must be matched by the outward change of our lives.  Chosen by God the Father, redeemed by God the Son, sealed by God the Spirit, our lives must be marked by the constraining love of God to walk after the Spirit.

4 JANUARY.part3: VERSE 1 In his epistle to the Galatians, Paul gives two
4 JANUARY.part7: There is therefore now no condemnation to them which are in Christ Jesus, who walk not after the flesh, but after the Spirit.  THOUGHT  ecause of the lust (or desire) of the flesh, an unregenerate person cannot do good, even though he knows he should and may even have an inner desire to do so. Like a person suffering from substance abuse who knows the dreadful consequences of addiction, he may even have the desire not to take the next puff, or the next drink or the next throw of the dice, but he cannot overcome his addiction because he is driven and controlled by his desire. In his epistle to the Galatians, Paul gives two contrasting lists: the works of the flesh and the fruit of the Spirit [Galatians 5:19-23]. It is interesting to note that Paul presents the works of the flesh as a list of multiple transgressions while the fruit of the Spirit is singular. The fruit of the Spirit comes in one package. The works of the flesh are carried out individually. That means an unsaved person may manifest one or more of the works of the flesh and even some of the attributes of the fruit of the Spirit. This makes it easier for unbelievers to be deceived about their standing before God. The Bible has multiple warnings for "so-called" brethren [1 Corinthians 5:11]; those who think they are saved when they are really lost. Our Lord Jesus warns: "I never knew you: depart from me, ye that work iniquity" [Matthew 7:23]. Paul also says: "Know ye not that the unrighteous shall not inherit the kingdom of God? Be not deceived ..." [1 Corinthians 6:9]. "Be not deceived; God is not mocked: for whatsoever a man soweth, that shall he also reap" [Galatians 6:7]. Even so, we shall be known by our fruits. Ye shall know them by their fruits ... Every good tree bringeth forth good fruit; but a corrupt tree bringeth forth evil fruit. A good tree cannot bring forth evil fruit, neither can a corrupt tree bring forth good fruit. - Matthew 7:16-19

5 JANUARY.part7: There is therefore now no condemnation to them which are in Christ Jesus, who walk not after the flesh, but after the Spirit.  THOUGHT  ust as the works of the flesh are evident in a person who is walking after the flesh - "now the works of the flesh are manifest ..." [Galatians 5:19-21] - so likewise must the fruit of the Spirit be evident in God's people. "The fruit of the Spirit is love, joy, peace, longsuffering, gentleness, goodness, faith, meekness, temperance: against such there is no law" [Galatians 5:22-23]. Doing things per se do not save the sinner; neither do they define a spiritual person. This is not a fleshly work; it is not a matter of raising a hand at a Gospel meeting, saying a prayer, or being kind and loving. These spiritual graces are the natural outflow of one who is conscientiously walking after the Spirit of God. To be sure, the fruit will not be developed to the fullest measure in every believer - nor can it be this side of eternity. The reason is that although all born-again Christians have the Holy Spirit indwelling them - they are "in Christ" - they are not always controlled by the Spirit of Christ. However, every believer must evidence all the attributes of the fruit of the Spirit, and it must be a growing fruit. By the Spirit's power, we are being continually restrained from doing the evil that is presented to us, and we are more and more being constrained by the love of God so that those evil things we would otherwise do, we no longer do. The extent to which we bear the Spirit's fruit depends on our walking after the Spirit, meaning obedience to God's Word and being controlled by the Spirit.  A Christian is a whole-hearted and one-minded person who is walking after the Spirit.

6 JANUARY.part7: There is therefore now no condemnation to them which are in Christ Jesus, who walk not after the flesh, but after the Spirit.  THOUGHT  n Romans 8, we can imagine Paul having a dialogue with his readers. Paul first makes the statement: "There is therefore now no condemnation to them which are in Christ Jesus". That leads to the people asking Paul: "Who are those who are in Christ?" Paul's answer: "These would be those 'who walk not after the flesh, but after the Spirit.'" Who are those "who walk not after the flesh"? There are some who believe that these are people who no longer have a sin nature; people who do not at all respond to the desires of the flesh. But that is not what Paul means. When Paul refers to those "who walk not after the flesh", he is speaking of those who have no confidence in the flesh. Their hope is not in their works. Their salvation is not in their will. Their sanctification is not of their own doing. No man, honest with himself, is going to lean on the arm of the flesh to be saved and to be sanctified. That is why Paul adds that not to walk after the flesh is to walk after the Spirit. That means the Spirit convicts, regenerates, seals, and leads the sinner. On our part, we repent when the Spirit convicts. We imbibe what the Spirit teaches. We receive what the Spirit reveals. And we follow where the Spirit leads. "Where does the Spirit lead?" He is the Spirit of truth [John 14:17; 15:26; 16:13] so He will never lead us to error. He is the Holy Spirit so He will never lead us in the path of unrighteousness. He came from the Father [John 15:26] so He will lead us back to the Father and life everlasting, and free us "from the law of sin and death" [v. 2].  The Spirit will never lead us away from truth into error. He will never lead us away from righteousness into sin.

7 JANUARY.part2: The Law of the Spirit of Life
7 JANUARY.part7: For the law of the Spirit of life in Christ Jesus hath made me free from the law of sin and death.  THOUGHT  n Romans 8:1, Paul contrasts the walk after the flesh with the walk after the Spirit. In verse 2, Paul makes a second contrast - the law of the Spirit of life in Christ Jesus against the law of sin and death. This contrast between the flesh and the Spirit is prevalent in the New Testament. Paul writes that "the flesh lusteth against the Spirit, and the Spirit against the flesh: and these are contrary the one to the other" [Galatians 5:17]. The two laws stand in absolute contradistinction. What is the law of the Spirit of life in Christ Jesus? First, the law of the Spirit of life in Christ is the glorious law of the Gospel of Christ that frees us from enslavement to sin as opposed to the old law that enslaves us in sin and death. Second, the law of the Spirit of life in Christ works in us, transforming our hearts and minds beyond just behavioural conformity to some external law. All men are born with a natural tendency to do the works of the flesh, which leads to death. The law of the Spirit of life in Christ works in us to lead us away from the way of sin to a new life in our Saviour. The Psalmist writes: "Thy word have I hid in mine heart, that I might not sin against thee" [Psalm 119:11]. Third, the law of the Spirit of life in Christ frees us from the burden to follow and keep God's Law for salvation. Christ fulfilled the law on our behalf so that we do not have to obey to the jot and tittle the law in order to be accepted by God.  The demands of the law send us to Christ to be saved, and Christ sends us back to the law to be sanctified.

8 JANUARY.part2: Freedom from the Law of Sin  and death
8 JANUARY.part7: For the law of the Spirit of life in Christ Jesus hath made me free from the law of sin and death.  THOUGHT  n the Garden of Eden, God warned Adam, "Of every tree of the garden thou mayest freely eat: But of the tree of the knowledge of good and evil, thou shalt not eat of it: for in the day that thou eatest thereof thou shalt surely die" [Genesis 2:1617]. When Adam defied God's word and ate the forbidden fruit, the curse - the law of sin and death - went into effect. And it remains in effect even today. "Wherefore, as by one man sin entered into the world, and death by sin; and so death passed upon all men, for that all have sinned" [Romans 5:12]. However, by the mercies of God, there is a law that trumps the law of sin and death, which is the law of the Spirit of life in Christ Jesus. We see this law operating in the life of the apostle Paul, who was "breathing out threatenings and slaughter against the disciples of the Lord" [Acts 9:1], but when Christ stopped him on the Damascus road, Paul was completely changed. And he later testified, "I am crucified with Christ: nevertheless I live; yet not I, but Christ liveth in me: and the life which I now live in the flesh I live by the faith of the Son of God, who loved me, and gave himself for me" [Galatians 2:20]. In the Christian, there remains a residual hold of the law of sin, accounting for the continual spiritual struggle in us [Romans 7:15-24]. But as we walk with God, we will find ourselves more and more opposed to the strong hold of the law of sin. May that be our heart's desire indeed.  "It is the spirit that quickeneth (gives life); the flesh profiteth nothing: the words that I speak unto you, they are spirit, and they are life" (John 6:63). The law of sin brings death. The Holy Spirit brings life.

9 JANUARY.part7: For what the law could not do, in that it was weak through the flesh, God sending his own Son in the likeness of sinful flesh, and for sin, condemned sin in the flesh:  THOUGHT  n Romans 8:2, we read that it takes the law of the Spirit of life in Christ Jesus to free us from the law of sin and death. The basis for this new law in the believer is the death of Jesus Christ. The law cannot bring us life. "Therefore by the deeds of the law there shall no flesh be justified in his sight: for by the law is the knowledge of sin" [Romans 3:20]. Sinners are "justified by faith without the deeds of the law" [Romans 3:28]. The law is not set up to save. The intent of the law is to expose and condemn sin. The law is given to define what sin is and what righteousness is, but it is weak through our flesh. The law can only command us to do what is right and not do what is wrong, and while it demands perfect obedience, it does not have the means to enable us to be obedient. That is why we cannot be free from the law's condemnation. For this reason, the law can only condemn us; it cannot save us. Living in Singapore - a country known for its strict law and order - Christians have to remember that we cannot produce godliness in our society by making laws. That is a fool's venture. It does not work. It has never worked, and it will never work. The only way we can produce godliness in a nation is to win more sinners to the kingdom of God and let them be the salt of the earth and light for Christ.  Righteousness (of God) exalteth a nation: but sin is a reproach to any people. - Proverbs 14:34

10 JANUARY.part7: For what the law could not do, in that it was weak through the flesh, God sending his own Son in the likeness of sinful flesh, and for sin, condemned sin in the flesh:  THOUGHT  he law cannot do anything to make us righteous because it cannot do anything to take away our sins. In a court of law, if a person is found guilty, the law can only exact judgement on the person. But what the laws could not do, the judge can. The judge has the authority to reduce the punishment, and even let the person off. Similarly, in the court of heaven, the law of God has no means of letting sinners get away with sin. "The soul that sinneth, it shall die" [Ezekiel 18:4, 20]. However, what the law could not do through the weakness of our flesh, God did by sending His own Son in the likeness of sinful flesh on account of sin: And He condemned sin in the flesh. A perfect illustration of the impotence of the law and the omnipotence of God is seen in the story of the woman caught in adultery [John 8:311]. The scribes and Pharisees brought her before Jesus and asked, "Master ... Moses in the law commanded us, that such should be stoned: but what sayest thou?" [John 8:4-5]. According to the law, she deserved death. The law could not save her. When the scribes and Pharisees pressed Jesus for His answer, He said to them: "He that is without sin among you, let him first cast a stone at her" [John 8:7]. And all the accusers slinked away. Christ then said to the woman, "Neither do I condemn thee: go, and sin no more" [John 8:11]. The law condemned the adulteress (all her accusers and us too), but the Lord Jesus Christ set her free. God did the same for us through Christ who suffered the penalty of our sins on the cross. Christ "Who His own self bare our sins in His own body on the tree, that we, being dead to sins, should live unto righteousness: by whose stripes ye were healed." [1 Peter 2:24]

11 JANUARY.part7: For what the law could not do, in that it was weak through the flesh, God sending his own Son in the likeness of sinful flesh, and for sin, condemned sin in the flesh:  THOUGHT  e might have just celebrated Christmas three weeks ago, but there is never a time when it is out of place to speak of the incarnation of Christ. Martin Luther - the 16th century Reformer - preached countless sermons on the first advent of Christ and the power of His incarnation, helping the people understand the true meaning of Christmas. He writes: "Read and meditate upon the nativity. If the meditation does not reach the heart, we shall sense no sweetness. The heart will not laugh or be merry. There is such richness and goodness in this nativity that if we should see and deeply understand, we should be caught up in perpetual joy." In his most famous carol - one of several he composed - Luther wrote: "From heaven high I come to you. I bring you tidings good and new. Glad tidings of great joy I bring, whereof I now will say and sing. To you this night is born a child, Of Mary, chosen, virgin, mild. This little child of lowly birth, Shall be the joy of all the earth." Luther would go on to express his joy in Christ for another 15 stanzas. If there is one thing Luther loved more than Christmas, it is the doctrine of justification by faith alone in Christ without works. Luther says, "We cannot grasp or exhaust Christ the eternal righteousness with one sermon. We are to learn to appreciate him as an everlasting lesson which we shall not be able to finish either in this life or in the life to come." Luther believed justification by faith alone in Christ is the chief article of Christian doctrine and the prince of theology. And while he preached many sermons on the incarnation, he preached many more about the doctrine of justification. The doctrine of justification by faith alone in Christ is the heart of the Christian faith and our life itself.

12 JANUARY.part7: For what the law could not do, in that it was weak through the flesh, God sending his own Son in the likeness of sinful flesh, and for sin, condemned sin in the flesh:  THOUGHT  he Bible asserts that Jesus is the God-Man. God incarnate - "the Word was made flesh, and dwelt among us" [John 1:14]. Christ "took not on Him the nature of angels; but He took on him the seed of Abraham" [Hebrews 2:16]. He "took upon Him the form of a servant, and was made in the likeness of men" [Philippians 2:7]. The Westminster Confession of Faith also teaches: "The Son of God, the second person of the Trinity, being very and eternal God, of one substance and equal with the Father, did, when the fullness of time was come, take upon Him man's nature, with all the essential properties and common infirmities thereof, yet without sin..." [WCF, Chapter 8.2]. So essential is this doctrine to Christianity that the apostle John describes those who deny the incarnation of Christ as "a deceiver and an antichrist" [2 John 7; 1 John 4:3]. Confessing that Jesus Christ is God come in human flesh is necessary to the Christian faith because this doctrine is so intricately connected to other doctrines - the deity of Christ, His impeccability, the efficacy of His redemptive work. No one who denies this doctrine can be said to be born-again. Christ is the God-Man, meaning that when Christ took on human flesh, He was neither a demigod (less than God in divine attributes) nor a superman (more than man in human faculties). In His condescension, Christ was fully man, but He remained fully God. The Confession puts it this way - "Which person is very God and very man, yet one Christ, the only Mediator between God and man." [WCF, Chapter 8.2] Christ is God from the essence of the Father, begotten before time; and he is human from the essence of his mother, born in time; completely God, completely human, with a rational soul and human flesh; equal to the Father as regards divinity, less than the Father as regards humanity. [Athanasian Creed]

13 JANUARY.part7: For what the law could not do, in that it was weak through the flesh, God sending his own Son in the likeness of sinful flesh, and for sin, condemned sin in the flesh:  THOUGHT  n the fourth century (AD 300s), a doctrinal controversy broke out between two theologians - Arius and Athanasius. The point of contention was the nature and the essence of Christ. Was Christ the same as God or was Christ similar to God? The debate was really over one letter. Arius argued for homoiousios - a compound word comprising "homoi" (similar) and "ousia" (substance) - teaching that God the Son is similar to God the Father, but not identical. Athanasius, on the other hand, argued for homoousios - "homo" (same) - that God the Son is the same as God the Father, having the same essence and nature. Whatever God the Father is, God the Son is too. To resolve this controversy, Emperor Constantine convened the Council of Nicaea in 325 AD which put an end to it, although the influence of Arianism persisted in the church for centuries. The happy outcome of that Council was the Nicene Creed which affirms the doctrine of homoousios, that God the Son is the same as God the Father. When Christ "was made flesh", Paul says that Christ was "made in the likeness of men" [Philippians 2:7]; that He was sent "in the likeness of sinful flesh". "Likeness" - in Greek homoiomati - carries the concept of similarity and not sameness. For Paul to say that Jesus came in sinful flesh would have contradicted the clear New Testament teaching of the sinless nature of Jesus. By coming in a state similar to human nature, our Lord Jesus is able to identify with our miseries, frailties and pain without Himself becoming defiled by sin. "For we have not an high priest which cannot be touched with the feeling of our infirmities; but was in all points tempted like as we are, yet without sin" [Hebrews 4:15]. The assurance of our salvation is based on the fact that we have a sinless Saviour.

14 JANUARY.part7: For what the law could not do, in that it was weak through the flesh, God sending his own Son in the likeness of sinful flesh, and for sin, condemned sin in the flesh:  THOUGHT  s we have noted (9 January reading), the law's intent is to condemn sin, but it is unable to destroy its power. The condemnation of sin can only come by God sending "His Son in the likeness of sinful flesh, and for sin, condemned sin in the flesh". God sent His Son "for sin". That is the purpose of Christ coming into the world. The incarnation of Christ has no relevance apart from the fact of sin. He is "the Lamb of God, which taketh away the sin of the world." [John 1:29] God sent His Son to condemn sin. The word "condemn" as used by Paul (also in Romans 8:1) comprises both pronouncement and execution. In other words, God not only declares sin to be what it is but also executes judgment upon it. God most certainly and definitively destroyed the power of sin. God sent His Son to condemn sin in the flesh. In other words, God condemned sin in Christ's flesh - in His human nature. We must never forget that it is in our place Christ bore the wrath of God against sin [Romans 5:6-9]. We must take note it is not just sin in the flesh that was condemned, but that sin was condemned through the flesh. Christ was made sin for us [2 Corinthians 5:21]. He bore "our sins in His own body on the tree" [1 Peter 2:24]. "He was wounded for our transgressions; He was bruised for our iniquities" [Isaiah 53:5]. The empty cross and empty tomb are our assurance that God has decisively condemned sin in the flesh. They are also our confidence that through Christ, we have victory over sin and death. Sin was judicially dealt with in the flesh. Sin has thus no more rights in us now. Praise the LORD that in Christ, there is not the slightest possibility of condemnation.

15 JANUARY.part3: VERSE 4 us "it is not possible that the blood of bulls and of
15 JANUARY.part7: That the righteousness of the law might be fulfilled in us, who walk not after the flesh, but after the Spirit.  THOUGHT  he very purpose of God sending His Son is so that sin may be condemned in the flesh and that "the righteousness of the law might be fulfilled in us". Romans 8:4 speaks both of our justification [v. 4a] as well as our sanctification [v. 4b]. Our Lord Jesus Christ, by His sacrificial death on the cross, condemned sin in the flesh and fulfilled the demands of the law, as our substitute. Christ fulfilled the ceremonial law. Hebrews tells us "it is not possible that the blood of bulls and of goats should take away sins" [Hebrews 10:4], but Christ, "by His own blood he entered in once into the holy place, having obtained eternal redemption for us" [Hebrews 9:12]. The righteousness of the law demands our complete and active obedience to it so that we may be justified. The law must be perfectly and intensely obeyed to the jot and tittle in every aspect of our lives. We must be sinless in thought, word and deed. We must be innocent as Adam originally was in the Garden, and the angels in heaven. Because of the sinfulness of our flesh, this is humanly impossible. We can never fulfil the law in our own persons and by our own wills. Christ fulfilled the moral law perfectly and intensely. And by His obedience to it, we are made righteous. Christ, the sinless One was made sin for us so "that we might be made the righteousness of God in Him" [2 Corinthians 5:21]. In His grace, Christ steps into our lives, but that is not where it ends. The Gospel is not antinomian. We who have been justified are also sanctified. Holiness is the fruit and evidence of reconciliation with God.  Christ, God's beloved, condemned as though His foe. He, as though I, accursed and left alone; I, as though He, embraced and welcomed home! - His Robes for Mine

16 JANUARY.part3: VERSE 4 Ephesians that "we are His workmanship, created
16 JANUARY.part7: That the righteousness of the law might be fulfilled in us, who walk not after the flesh, but after the Spirit.  THOUGHT  God sending his own Son in the likeness of sinful flesh" - that is Christ's incarnation. "For (our) sin, condemned sin in the flesh" [v. 3] - that is the reason for His sacrificial death. But it must be pointed out that Christ died to save us not merely in our sins, but also from our sins. God condemned sin through His Son so that holiness might appear in us. That is what Paul meant when he says to the Ephesians that "we are His workmanship, created in Christ Jesus unto good works, which God hath before ordained that we should walk in them" [Ephesians 2:10]. God has ordained the double ends - the good works and the workers of those works (that is, you, I, and all believers). God has also ordained the means so that we would be enabled to accomplish the good works that He has specifically appointed for us. Thus, it is important for us to know the good works for which God has saved us to do, and to actually do them. There is a reason God has set you at this point of your life in the place where you are. Esther was hesitant to do the good works God had ordained for her until Mordecai posed her this question - "Who knoweth whether thou art come to the kingdom for such a time as this?" [Esther 4:14]. As God's people, we too must know the purpose for which we are on earth. And there is no greater confidence for and no greater joy in our lives than to know we are walking in the way that God has set for us.  God has made us alive in Christ so that we might live for Him. God saved us by His grace so that we may extend grace to the people who cross our paths.

17 JANUARY.part3: VERSE 4 to the spices that they used [Matthew 23:23]. The
17 JANUARY.part7: That the righteousness of the law might be fulfilled in us, who walk not after the flesh, but after the Spirit.  THOUGHT  Except your righteousness shall exceed the righteousness of the scribes and Pharisees, ye shall in no case enter into the kingdom of heaven" [Matthew 5:20]. By a cursory reading of these words, it seems the Lord Jesus has set an impossible standard for our entrance into God's kingdom. To the average Jew, who could be more righteous than the scribes and the Pharisees? They were known for their strict keeping of the law. The law called for tithing, and so they did, down to the spices that they used [Matthew 23:23]. The law called for keeping the Sabbath holy, so they would not even lift a finger to do works of mercy. Even Paul, before his conversion, boasted that as "touching the righteousness which is in the law, (he was) blameless" [Philippians 3:6]. But the Pharisees were not righteous - not by God's standards. They were self-righteous, and self-righteousness is defective righteousness. What is defective righteousness? These are "good works" that come neither from a sincere heart nor done according to the principles of grace. The Pharisees carried out these acts not for God's glory but for man's applause. The Pharisees did "good works" so they could be seen by men, and Jesus said "they have their reward" [Matthew 6:2], but reward only on earth with adulation from man, and not reward in heaven with approval from God. These are also works that "have omitted the weightier matters of the law" [Matthew 23:23]. The Pharisees satisfied themselves with occasional external works that impress others, rather than good works from a transformed heart that truly please God. Do good works of righteousness, but "let not thy left hand know what thy right hand doeth ... and thy Father which seeth in secret Himself shall reward thee openly" [Matthew 6:3-4].

18 JANUARY.part7: That the righteousness of the law might be fulfilled in us, who walk not after the flesh, but after the Spirit.  PRAYER  hen our Lord Jesus says that unless our "righteousness shall exceed the righteousness of the scribes and Pharisees, (we) shall in no case enter into the kingdom of heaven" [Matthew 5:20], He is emphasizing the need for righteousness as a condition for admission into God's kingdom. It was the loss of righteousness that caused Adam and Eve to be expelled from the Garden of Eden in the first place. If God were to admit us into heaven without righteousness, it would go against the very nature of His justice. Unlike the self-righteousness of the Pharisees in our Lord's time, the present age is dominated by an antinomian spirit. The view that says, "As long as I feel good and right and do not hurt anyone, the law is irrelevant." There are Christian preachers who say that the Ten Commandments are passe, claiming that our sins - past, present, and future - have been forgiven. We are in the age of grace and therefore the commandments in God's Word have no part in the Christian's life. It is an egregious doctrinal error dispelled by our Lord Jesus Christ who says, "If ye love me, keep my commandments" [John 14:15]. And in Romans 13:9, Paul applies the second table of the law to Christians, adding that "love (for God) is the fulfilling of the law" [Romans 13:9-10]. A "pharisaical" righteousness will not bring a sinner into God's kingdom, but neither should a person count on "lawless" grace to save him. The grace of God does not nullify His moral law. Law and grace are not contradictory. They complement each other. We are saved by the grace of God and empowered by the Holy Spirit to walk in holiness. Not my righteousness, O Lord but Thine for Thou are Jehovah Tsidkenu - "In his days Judah shall be saved, and Israel shall dwell safely: and this is his name whereby he shall be called, THE LORD OUR RIGHTEOUSNESS." [Jeremiah 23:6; 33:16]

19 JANUARY.part2: Holiness and the Work of  the Holy Spirit
19 JANUARY.part7: That the righteousness of the law might be fulfilled in us, who walk not after the flesh, but after the Spirit.  THOUGHT  he Pharisee counts on his own righteousness. At the other end of the spectrum, the antinomian believes that grace exempts him from obeying the law. The Christian lives with confidence in the saving grace of Christ but also in the reality that he is still susceptible to the temptations of the devil and the world, and the weakness of his own flesh. Christians can sin - and still do. The law serves as a guide as we tread this treacherous world. In Romans 7, Paul said that before his conversion, as much as he loved the law of God, he could not keep the law. But after his conversion, he discovered that he could not keep the law by himself. The things that he should do, he did not, but the things that he should not do, he did. And he discovered that by his own flesh, he could not walk after the Spirit. Only by the presence and power of the Holy Spirit could he walk after the Spirit. This reality leads to two conclusions: First, the Holy Spirit is vital to holy living. The Holy Spirit who indwells us will teach us all things, bring all things to our remembrance, and guide us in all truth [John 14:17, 26; 16:13] so that we may know the Word of God and walk in the path of truth and righteousness. Second, we must work at this relationship by our obeying God's Word and submitting to the Spirit's guidance. Paul exhorts us to "yield (ourselves) unto God, as those that are alive from the dead, and (our) members as instruments of righteousness unto God" [Romans 6:13].  As God's redeemed, we must seek the Spirit's guidance and rely on His power for our holiness.

20 JANUARY.part3: VERSE 4 the unholy state of Christians and their churches?
20 JANUARY.part7: That the righteousness of the law might be fulfilled in us, who walk not after the flesh, but after the Spirit.  PRAYER  person must follow Christ to be a Christian. There is no other way. The person who claims to be a Christian must also reflect the nature of Christ. "As He which hath called you is holy, so be ye holy in all manner of conversation; Because it is written, Be ye holy; for I am holy" [1 Peter 1:15-16; Leviticus 20:7]. That begs the question - if holiness is the nature of Christ and Christians, how do we account for the unholy state of Christians and their churches? Sadly, there is an observable divide between the claim and the character, between the talk and the walk. While it is easy to point the finger at others, the revival of religion lands squarely on the shoulders of individuals - you and I. To the extent we are personally revived, the church will be revived. A study of the history of revivals shows it happens in three phases. First is the realisation we are not what we ought to be. This is an awakening to the truth so that counterfeit believers and lukewarm Christians are brought to see their true spiritual condition. The second phase is revival, in which genuine believers are brought to spiritual life again. With this comes a growing spiritual vitality, and a thirst and hunger for God's truth and righteousness. The third phase - impact on society - follows naturally. Just as salt will flavour food, and light will dispel darkness, the spiritually-revived Christian will make an impact in his home, community and workplace. How we need a true evangelical revival in our day. Spiritual revival is like a ripple; it begins with you, your family, your church and then society at large. Lord, send a revival and let it begin with me.

21 JANUARY.part7: For they that are after the flesh do mind the things of the flesh; but they that are after the Spirit the things of the Spirit.  THOUGHT  here are those who hold the view that we can classify the spiritual state of people in three ways - unbelievers, believers, and those who are believers but live like unbelievers, commonly known as carnal (fleshly-minded) Christians. Romans 8:5 tells us that there are really only two classes - believers and unbelievers. The third class of people is a misnomer. These are the ones who have imbibed the false teaching of preachers who assure them of "peace, peace; when there is no peace" [Jeremiah 6:14; 8:11]. Such spiritual delusion is destructive. "For they that are after the flesh do mind the things of the flesh". The word "flesh" (Greek: sarx), in its literal sense, refers to the fleshly part of man; it portrays man in his physical and earthly state [John 1:14; 1 John 4:2]. However, in the New Testament, "flesh" is commonly used as a metaphor denoting man's sinful nature - the unregenerate dimension of humanity. In this regard, the contrast is often made between the flesh and the spirit - either it is earthly in contrast to the heavenly, or it is the sinful in contrast to the life in Christ. So the natural man is under the control of his "sinful flesh", but the regenerate man is guided by the Spirit. The former is ruled by sin; the latter by God. Paul reminds us that to be fleshly-minded is to war against the Spirit of God [Galatians 5:17]. He adds that the "carnal (sarx) mind is enmity against God" [v. 7], which manifests itself in overt sinful behaviour [Galatians 5:19-21]. Just as it is unnatural and impossible for a sinner to live holily, so it is equally unnatural and egregious for a saint to continue to live in the flesh. That which is born of the flesh is flesh; and that which is born of the Spirit is spirit. - John 3:6

22 JANUARY.part7: For they that are after the flesh do mind the things of the flesh; but they that are after the Spirit the things of the Spirit.  THOUGHT  hen we think of those who "mind the things of the flesh", the tendency is to see a person who is engaged in fleshly sins - drunkenness, sexual promiscuity, lovers of pleasure, pride, etc. [Galatians 5:19-21; 2 Timothy 3:4]. In other words, we tend to think of sinful acts performed by unbelievers. However, to "mind the things of the flesh" has a larger scope in meaning. The word "mind" describes an attitude - a disposition of the mind; the allegiance of one's heart. It would include many things we may not usually describe as fleshly. In Romans 8:5, Paul is not just concerned about the sinful deeds; he is just as concerned about the sinful affections. Take Paul for example. Before his conversion, he said that as far as the law was concerned, he was "a Pharisee; concerning zeal, persecuting the church; touching the righteousness which is in the law, (he was) blameless" [Philippians 3:5-6]. In his lost state, Paul did not indulge in debauchery; quite the contrary, he was a strict moralist and a religious zealot. As a Pharisee, Paul would have followed the stringent moral rules, controlling every aspect of his life. Was Paul doing "the things of the flesh"? Assuredly not! But was he minding the things of the flesh? Most certainly! Such is the characteristic of the moral unbeliever, whose desire is to prove that by his own efforts, he is worthy of God's saving favour. Nothing so characterizes the thinking of the unbeliever than this delusion.  Christian, mind heavenly things. "Seek those things which are above ... Set your affection on things above, not on things on the earth" [Colossians 3:12].

23 JANUARY.part7: For they that are after the flesh do mind the things of the flesh; but they that are after the Spirit the things of the Spirit.  THOUGHT  he unbeliever sets his mind on what his own flesh desires. The believer, on the other hand, sets his mind on what the Spirit desires. This is the difference between one who is merely religious and one who is mindful of the things of the Spirit. The Pharisees were exceedingly religious; they kept the law meticulously, but they desired to kill the Lord Jesus. Saul of Tarsus was extremely religious even as he was creating havoc in the church and having Christians arrested and thrown into jail [Acts 9:2]. In making the contrast between the fleshlyminded and the spiritually-minded, Paul exposes the folly of those who are merely religious; those who merely ascribe to a set of orthodox theological beliefs; these who mistakenly think that as long as they believe, their sins will be forgiven, and God is obliged to save them. It is important to embrace biblical truth and believe in the right doctrines because without faith, it is impossible to please God. That said however, the Word of God reminds us that "the devils also believe, and tremble" [James 2:19]. There were many who saw the miracles of our Lord Jesus and believed in His name, but He "did not commit himself unto them, because he knew all men" [John 2:23-24]. To be a Christian is more than just giving verbal assent to a set of biblical doctrines; it is to be born again of the Spirit [John 3:5-6], and it is to be expected that one who is born of the Spirit will mind the things of the Spirit.  Our Christian conduct must be evident in our Christian confession.

24 JANUARY.part7: For they that are after the flesh do mind the things of the flesh; but they that are after the Spirit the things of the Spirit.  THOUGHT  hat is a Christian? What does being a Christian mean? You are a Christian when you are convicted of your sins, quickened by the power of the Holy Spirit to put your faith in the atoning work of Christ. And being regenerated, there is an inner transformation that causes you to set your heart and mind on the things of the Spirit so that your life is directed by the desires of the Spirit. It does not mean we are sinlessly perfect. It also does not mean we will always be walking in the Spirit, but it does mean that we want to. Our Lord Jesus says that a Christian is one who enters the strait gate and walks the narrow way. The narrow path is not the destination. The destination is eternal life in the presence of God. Walking the narrow path simply means we are moving along in the path of righteousness, following our Lord Jesus. In this life, we are not a finished product. We are in the process of being. And as we mind the things of the Spirit, we are daily being sanctified, like a rough stone being polished, like silver being refined. Now we are not like our Saviour, but one day, we will be. John puts it this way, "Beloved, now are we the sons of God, and it doth not yet appear what we shall be: but we know that, when he shall appear, we shall be like him; for we shall see him as he is" [1 John 3:2].  I am not what I ought to be; I am not what I want to be, I am not what I hope to be in another world; but still I am not what I once used to be, and by the grace of God I am what I am. - John Newton

25 JANUARY.part3: VERSE 6 5]. There is a link between what we think and how
25 JANUARY.part7: For to be carnally minded is death; but to be spiritually minded is life and peace.  THOUGHT  aul makes the contrast between a believer and an unbeliever. As the Gospel is preached, there will be two kinds of responses. Those who submit to God in repentance of sin with faith in Christ, and those who reject it. Both will then show in their lives the effects of believing or not. The believer will walk after the Spirit, but the unbeliever will walk after the flesh. "For they that are after the flesh do mind the things of the flesh; but they that are after the Spirit the things of the Spirit" [v. 5]. There is a link between what we think and how we live. Verse 6a reads "for to be carnally minded is death". Carnal-mindedness or flesh-mindedness means to think and live according to the desires of the flesh under the control of our sin nature, which leads to death. That is how we were before we were saved. After being born again in Christ, though we may still have a tendency to give in to carnal thinking, behaving like the ungodly and pursuing the lusts of the flesh - a life that displeases God; however, in Christ we have been delivered from helpless the bondage to sin, from the devil, and from the eternal death judgment. So, we must turn away from the sinful lifestyle of the flesh. We must heed God's Word and be resolved to shun evil for "the works of the flesh are manifest, which are these; Adultery, fornication, uncleanness, lasciviousness, idolatry, witchcraft, hatred, variance, emulations, wrath, strife, seditions, heresies, envyings, murders, drunkenness, revellings, and such like: of the which I tell you before, as I have also told you in time past, that they which do such things shall not inherit the kingdom of God" [Galatians 5:19-21]. And they that are Christ's have crucified the flesh with the affections and lusts. - Galatians 5:24

26 JANUARY.part7: For to be carnally minded is death; but to be spiritually minded is life and peace.  THOUGHT  hen God saved us by His grace through the finished work of His Son Jesus Christ, the Holy Spirit indwelled us, enabling us to live the new life in Christ. This does not mean we have attained moral perfection in our body of flesh. We still face manifold temptations. Why? "For the flesh lusteth against the Spirit, and the Spirit against the flesh: and these are contrary the one to the other: so that ye cannot do the things that ye would" [Galatians 5:17]. The good news is that God has given us the power to live victoriously for Him. "For God hath not given us the spirit of fear; but of power, and of love, and of a sound mind" [2 Timothy 1:7]. This sound mind speaks of the God-given ability to think on the things of God, on spiritual things. How we think will result in how we act. If we train our minds to think spiritually in accordance with God's teaching, it will be life and peace. "Thou wilt keep him in perfect peace, whose mind is stayed on Thee: because he trusteth in Thee" [Isaiah 26:3]. But if we allow our minds to think things that pander to the lusts of the flesh, our bodies will take control of our lives and we will live and behave as if we were not saved. How do we train ourselves to think spiritually? Answer: "If we live in the Spirit, let us also walk in the Spirit" [Galatians 5:25]. Indeed, "this I say then, Walk in the Spirit, and ye shall not fulfil the lust of the flesh" [Galatians 5:16].  A spiritually-minded believer manifests the fruit of the Holy Spirit which "is love, joy, peace, longsuffering, gentleness, goodness, faith, meekness, temperance: against such there is no law" [Galatians 5:22-23].

But thank God who "commendeth His love toward us, in that, while we were yet sinners, Christ died for us ... when we were enemies, we were reconciled to God by the death of his Son" [Romans 5:8, 10]. By the mercies and grace of God, we turned to Christ and were born again spiritually with a new inner nature able to live for God. We still struggle with the outer corrupt body of flesh that tries to lure us back into the old sinful ways. The battleground is in what and how we think - whether spiritually or carnally. If we give in to the temptation of carnal thinking, we are again behaving like an enemy of God. Perhaps you think you are not an enemy of God like a hard-core criminal. But God's enemy is anyone with an attitude of indifference toward Him - a heart that is neither hot nor cold toward Him. May the Lord help us to be true unto Him according to His word in John 15:14 "Ye are My friends, if ye do whatsoever I command you."  Search me, O God, and know my heart: try me, and know my thoughts. - Psalm 139:23

28 JANUARY.part7: So then they that are in the flesh cannot please God.  THOUGHT  he phrase "in the flesh" taken by itself speaks of the unsaved who by nature live for themselves to satisfy their lustful appetites inherited from Adam's sin nature. Under the controlling power of sin, the flesh cannot do the things which please God. Such are already spiritually dead in their sin and trespasses. That is why no amount of good works done can save them from God's wrath. Following the reasoning in Romans 8:7 that the carnally minded are enemies of God in defiance of His law, Paul emphasizes that in the flesh they cannot please God. Here Paul warns believers they should not live their lives as before, in the way of the flesh. This is important because even though the souls of believers are saved by grace, they are still in the body of unredeemed flesh waiting to put on the incorruptible glorified body at the return of our Lord Jesus Christ. Meanwhile, believers experience conflicts within like what Paul experienced. "For I know that in me (that is, in my flesh,) dwelleth no good thing: for to will is present with me; but how to perform that which is good I find not. For the good that I would I do not: but the evil which I would not, that I do" [Romans 7:18-19]. The point is this - the reason we struggle is that our unredeemed flesh with its sinful tendencies has no ability to please God. Therefore, the only way to subdue the flesh is to maintain our walk in the power of the Holy Spirit and bear spiritual fruit within [Galatians 5:16, 22-23]. Our help is from the Lord.  Not by works of righteousness which we have done, but according to His mercy He saved us, by the washing of regeneration, and renewing of the Holy Ghost. - Titus 3:5

29 JANUARY.part7: But ye are not in the flesh, but in the Spirit, if so be that the Spirit of God dwell in you. Now if any man have not the Spirit of Christ, he is none of his.  THOUGHT  he person delivered from sin's bondage and condemnation by Jesus Christ will be a different person. The inspired Bible writers describe them in various ways. He was blind walking in darkness before but now he has sight and abides in the light. He is a new creation versus the old. a citizen of heaven versus a citizen of the world, a slave to righteousness versus a slave to sin. Now born again, he is a child of God, no more a child of the devil. The new man is spiritual, while the old man was carnal. Here the apostle describes him as being in the Spirit, no more in the flesh. There must be a difference between who he is now and what he was before, or something is terribly amiss. The Christian's past was marked by a love of sin and indulgence in it. He now seeks after righteousness and strives for it because that pleases his new Master and glorifies God. Before, he sought only worldly things - "the lust of the flesh, the lust of the eye and the pride of life," now he seeks to lay up treasures where moth and rust do not corrupt or thieves break in to steal. Before, his roots were sunk deep in this world, now he looks for a city with eternal foundations, whose builder and maker is God. He is wise and hears his Master's voice; he does His bidding thus building his house upon a rock, not sand. Dear friend, is your new life in the Spirit consistent with what has been described above and evidenced by fruit to God's glory or is it a fruitless fruit tree that will be hewn down and cast aside in the final reckoning because it is useless to anyone? [Matthew 7:16-20]  Can the fig tree, my brethren, bear olive berries? either a vine, figs? so can no fountain both yield salt water and fresh. - James 3:12

30 JANUARY.part7: But ye are not in the flesh, but in the Spirit, if so be that the Spirit of God dwell in you. Now if any man have not the Spirit of Christ, he is none of his.  THOUGHT  hat is the difference between the person born "in the flesh" and the person born again "in the Spirit"? Is he different in appearance? Maybe. Sound different? Probably. Does he think and live life differently? Certainly. What accounts for the difference in one who has repented of his sin, received forgiveness and now trusts and follows Christ as his Saviour and Lord? It is that the Holy Spirit now dwells in him. Before he was a child of the fallen Adam, a slave to the prince of this world, the devil. Now he belongs to Christ, the sinless second Adam, freed from sin's penalty, born the second time not in the flesh but in the Spirit and indwelt by Him. What does it mean for us who are indwelt by the Spirit? It means the Holy Spirit is present with us perpetually. When we need God's guidance, the Holy Spirit is there as our Counsellor. When in need of comfort, He is our Comforter. When weak, He gives us strength. When we lack wisdom, we ask and He supplies. When life overwhelms, and we do not know what to pray, He teaches us and intercedes for us at the throne of grace. "Emmanuel, God with us" [Isaiah 7:14, Matthew 1:23] is not merely the prophecy and promise of God the Son Incarnate, but it is also an unequivocal statement of God the Spirit's perpetual presence with, habitation in and possession of the regenerate soul in Christ so that no more does sin have any claim on him. The Spirit's indwelling is the seal that a person is loved by and belongs to God forever. His is God's power and presence available only to His own. In the words of the modern gospel song, "My chains are gone, I've been set free, Unending love, Amazing grace". God's sublime promise that "I will never leave thee, nor forsake thee" [Hebrews 13:5] is confirmed by the Holy Spirit indwelling us.

As Jesus prepared his disciples for His imminent departure, He gave them the promise of the Holy Spirit whom God the Father would send to be their Comforter (or Helper) in His place, the Spirit of truth which the world cannot receive because they do not know Him [John 14:16-17]. He will enter and dwell in the believers' hearts as a seal of their special standing as God's possession, saved by grace through faith in Jesus Christ. For ye are bought with a price: therefore glorify God in your body, and in your spirit, which are God's" [1 Corinthians 6:19-20]. The indwelling of the Spirit is the sole prerogative, special privilege and personal possession of the redeemed, who will henceforth be empowered to glorify God. If we deny the Spirit, we deny Christ. If we quench the Spirit, we deprive ourselves of His saving power. If we resist the Spirit, we despise God Almighty Himself and silence His divine voice of guidance and good conscience. God in His Spirit dwells with us. If we do not have the Spirit, then we do not have Christ and are still in our sins and condemned. Jesus Christ is the chief foundation stone and we are built together to be His holy temple, a habitation of God through the Spirit. Read Ephesians 2:2022.

1 FEBRUARY.part3: VERSE 10 penalty of his sins past, present and future has
1 FEBRUARY.part7: And if Christ be in you, the body is dead because of sin; but the Spirit is life because of righteousness.  THOUGHT  ow is Christ in the Christian? By the Holy Spirit dwelling in him. The Christian as a child of Adam has inherited the sin gene. Tainted by his first father's fall, his soul was lost but God in His sovereign grace provided a Redeemer born not of man's seed but woman's. This Saviour was Jesus Christ, the second person of the Trinity. The Christian, born again by the blood now has the Spirit of Christ abiding in him [v. 9]. The penalty of his sins past, present and future has been paid once and for all on the Cross [Hebrews 10:12]. But his former sin nature remains to trouble him while he occupies this temporal body of flesh. Thus arises a tussle between his old nature and his new. The Christian in whose heart the Spirit dwells and to whom he gives full reign is like the branch connected to the vine [John 15:4-5]. The branch is fruitful only because it draws its nourishment and strength from the stem. He may be troubled by the presence of residual sin and sinful tendencies arising from his old nature, yet he is able to resist and overcome because the power of God's Holy Spirit is his ever-present help. Apostle John testified to this in writing, "Ye are of God, little children, and have overcome them: because greater is he that is in you, than he that is in the world" [1 John 4:4]. The Spirit of God is greater than the spirit of the antichrist. The Holy Spirit within us is the proof and seal of our redemption and eternal ownership by God. This is our present state and standing. It is a great privilege and high calling to be children of God, heirs and joint-heirs with Christ, empowered by the Spirit, awaiting the great day of our glorification [v. 8:16-17]. And grieve not the holy Spirit of God, whereby ye are sealed unto the day of redemption. - Ephesians 4:30

2 FEBRUARY.part3: VERSE 10 [Philippians 2:13]. Christ 1s our new master, and
2 FEBRUARY.part7: And if Christ be in you, the body is dead because of sin; but the Spirit is life because of righteousness.  THOUGHT  f Christ be in us, then His Spirit of righteousness is in us [Romans 1:4]. What blessed thought that we are no more subject to the dictates of the evil one or the whims of the flesh as we once were. The Christian in Christ is dead to sin but alive to God because the Spirit is living and active in him [Romans 6:11]. God works in us "to will and do of His good pleasure" through the working of the Spirit [Philippians 2:13]. Christ is our new master, and we are freed from sin's enslavement, with liberty and ability not to do whatever we want but to do what we ought as Paul told the Corinthians, "Now the Lord is that Spirit: and where the Spirit of the Lord is, there is liberty." [2 Corinthians 3:17]. The Christian aspires to righteousness because Christ's Spirit of holiness lives in him [Romans 1:4]. The Christian regardless of his external circumstances is filled with inner joy and peace because he has the blessed hope of eternal life and the blessed assurance of divine companionship and ultimate victory through the Holy Spirit's power [Romans 15:13]. The Christian is able to bear fruit for God's glory because the Spirit of Christ is a river of life-giving waters within him. The Christian illuminated by the Spirit is able to discern and understand God's truth and believe His Word because he has the Spirit of truth [John 16:13] and the divine teacher [1 John 2:27]. Thus, the Christian can have faith in God whom he cannot see and believes His revelation of things yet to happen [Ephesians 1:17]. The Christian's life is one under control because the Holy Spirit is in control of it. The Spirit abides in us but we must abide in the Spirit. Therefore "Walk in the Spirit, and ye shall not fulfil the lust of the flesh" [Galatians 5:16].

3 FEBRUARY.part3: VERSE 11 Christ. The Holy Spirit then dwells in the hearts
3 FEBRUARY.part7: But if the Spirit of him that raised up Jesus from the dead dwell in you, he that raised up Christ from the dead shall also quicken your mortal bodies by his Spirit that dwelleth in you.  THOUGHT  t first glance, this verse may seem abstract. Actually, it is very clearly expressed. Here the apostle Paul wrote that the same Spirit that resurrected Jesus dwells in us (all who confess Jesus as their Saviour). God the Father, the Son (Jesus) and the Holy Spirit are all one. We were once at enmity with God and dead in our sins. But by God's grace, we were quickened (made alive) through the Lord Jesus Christ. The Holy Spirit then dwells in the hearts of every believer. Yes, the same Spirit Paul speaks about who raised Jesus dwells in us. Thus, we are now God's children. God, like any loving parent, cares for us, and He is listening when we pray. Just as the Lord Jesus was resurrected to die no more, we too will be resurrected and live forever. We will be in heaven after taking our last breath on earth. What is your response to such a privilege? We ought to have an obligation to the Spirit who lives in us. He walks with us, talks with us and guides us our entire life. "And even to your old age I am he; and even to hoar hairs will I carry you: I have made, and I will bear; even I will carry, and will deliver you" [Isaiah 46:4]. Therefore, we ought not to walk in the flesh again. We follow Christ, and as the Holy Spirit empowers us, we live as new creatures. "Imagine there's no heaven ... No hell below us. Above us only sky. Imagine all the people living for today." If you choose this path, you are like the rich fool the Lord warns about in His parable in Luke 12:16-21. Tragically, this is exactly the life many people today follow. Our Lord warned that this is the kind of world that will greet Him when He returns; "For as in the days that were before the flood they were eating and drinking, marrying and giving in marriage, until the day that Noe entered into the ark, And knew not until the flood came, and took them all away; so shall also the coming of the Son of man be." [Matthew 24:38-39]. Let us heed the Apostle's warning and choose life, not death.  There is a way that seemeth right unto a man, but the end thereof are the ways of death. - Proverbs 16:25

8 FEBRUARY.part7: For if ye live after the flesh, ye shall die: but if ye through the Spirit do mortify the deeds of the body, ye shall live.  THOUGHT  ll who hear the Gospel have to make a choice. If you choose to live after the flesh, you will die. The question then arises. Can a believer who has received the grace of God live after the flesh? The answer is no. While the sinful nature is still in the believer and may exert its influence, it will not have dominion. The true believer will not finally fall from his state of grace. But there will be a constant struggle with sin, a struggle that even the Apostle had to put up; and sometimes the flesh does get the upper hand and the believer stumbles and falls into sin. Paul says that believers have to mortify or put to death the deeds of the body. Deeds of the body refer to wicked deeds, evil lusts and passions, the desires and urges that lead to sin. The power to mortify the evil deeds of the body comes "through the Spirit". That means we need to have the Holy Spirit dwelling in us in the first place. We can find two excellent examples of godly men who were able to fend off the strongest temptations despite living in thoroughly pagan and godless societies. Joseph in Egypt was described as "a man in whom the Spirit of God is" [Genesis 41:38], and Daniel in Babylon was said to have "an excellent spirit" in him [Daniel 6:3]. If we are true followers of the Lord Jesus Christ, this same Holy Spirit indwells us, and He will help us in our struggle with sin.  Serving God in the spirit of adoption is true happiness. - James Smith, Daily Remembrancer

9 FEBRUARY.part7: For if ye live after the flesh, ye shall die: but if ye through the Spirit do mortify the deeds of the body, ye shall live.  THOUGHT  ur Lord says in Luke 9:23: "If any man will come after me, let him deny himself, and take up his cross daily, and follow me." Denying oneself daily is not easy. Often the (human) spirit is willing, but the flesh is weak. Paul says that we must put to death the deeds of the flesh. This has the idea of denying, subduing, deadening, destroying the strength of the flesh. The apostle Peter puts it this way in 1 Peter 4:2, "That he no longer should live the rest of his time in the flesh to the lusts of men, but to the will of God." However, even if we are willing to do it, we do not have the strength. We need the power of the Holy Spirit. Mortification of the flesh is a collaborative effort between us and the Holy Spirit within us. We must first have the will to deny the sinful desires and inclinations, and then the Spirit gives the strength to deaden and subdue their strength. He cannot destroy the strength of sin unless we exercise our will and work to destroy it ourselves, and we cannot will and work at it apart from Him. In this fight we need weapons. In Ephesians 6:17, Pauls says we need "the sword of the Spirit, which is the word of God". If you are one of those Christians who only open your Bible on Sunday mornings when the preacher asks you to do so, you can be sure that the flesh will have the upper hand and your defeat is certain.  The Bible will keep you from sin, or sin will keep you from the Bible. - Dwight L. Moody

10 FEBRUARY.part2: John Owen -- What Mortification of Sin is not?
10 FEBRUARY.part7: For if ye live after the flesh, ye shall die: but if ye through the Spirit do mortify the deeds of the body, ye shall live.  THOUGHT  ohn Owen (1616-1683) was a Puritan and a non-Conformist theologian. He was also one of the most prolific writers in the seventeenth century, writing over eight million words on topics that covered theology and spirituality, politics and economics, including the largest commentary ever published on the Epistle to the Hebrews. One of his many volumes was Mortification of Sin based on Romans 8:13. What is the mortification of sin? Owen writes: "To mortify a sin is not utterly to kill, root it out, and destroy it, so that it has no more hold at all nor residence in our hearts. It is true this is that which is aimed at, but this is not in this life to be accomplished. There is no man that truly sets himself to mortify any sin, but he aims at, intends, and desires its utter destruction so that it leaves neither root nor fruit in the heart or life. He would so kill it that it should never move nor stir any more, cry or call, seduce or tempt, to eternity." Owen also warns us of the diversion of sin, like Simon Magus who left his sorceries but diverted to covetousness and remained in the "gall of bitterness" (Acts 8:23). "A man may be sensible of a lust, set himself against the eruptions of it, take care that it shall not break forth as it has done, but in the meantime suffer the same corrupted habit to vent itself some other way ... The same is the case of trading lusts: a man's leaving off from serving one so that he may serve another. He that changes pride for worldliness ... let him not think that he has mortified the sin that he seems to have left. He has changed his master but is a servant still." Whose servant are you? "Know ye not, that to whom ye yield yourselves servants to obey, his servants ye are to whom ye obey; whether of sin unto death, or of obedience unto righteousness?" [Romans 6:16]

11 FEBRUARY.part2: John Owen -- What Mortification of Sin is?
11 FEBRUARY.part7: For if ye live after the flesh, ye shall die: but if ye through the Spirit do mortify the deeds of the body, ye shall live.  THOUGHT  wen writes that mortification of sin consists of three things: "The weakening of this habit of sin or lust ... a constant fighting and contending against sin ... (and) a frequent success against any lust." To be in constant battle against sin requires us to know the tempter. "To labour to be acquainted with the ways, wiles, methods, advantages, and occasions of sin's success is the beginning of this warfare. This is the way men deal with enemies. They inquire about their counsels and designs, ponder their goals, [and] consider how and by what means they have formerly prevailed, so that they may be prevented ... Indeed, men who mortify lust deal with it in this way. Not only when lust is actually vexing, enticing, and seducing, but in their quiet moments they consider, 'This is our enemy; this is his way and progress, these are his advantages, thus has he prevailed, and thus he will do, if not prevented.' So it was with David: 'My sin is ever before me' (Psalm 51:3). Indeed, one of the choicest and most eminent parts of spiritual wisdom, practically applied, consists in finding out the subtleties ... of any indwelling sin. A good part of our warfare is to consider and know - wherein its greatest strength lies; what advantage it takes of occasions, opportunities, and temptations; what are its pleas, pretenses, and reasonings; and what are its strategies, colors, and excuses. A good part of our warfare is - to set the wisdom of the Spirit against the craft of the old man; to trace this serpent in all its turnings and windings; to be able to say, at its most secret and imperceptible actings: 'This is your old way and course; I know what you aim at;' and so to be always in readiness." Be killing sin or it will be killing you.

14 FEBRUARY.part7: For as many as are led by the Spirit of God, they are the sons of God.  THOUGHT  n paternity suits, paternity can be determined by means of DNA tests. [Galatians 4:6] and leads us to live holy lives because God our Father is holy [1 Peter 1:15-16]. As obedient children, not fashioning yourselves according to the former lusts in your ignorance: But as he which hath called you is holy, so be ye holy in all manner of conversation. - 1 Peter 1:1415

15 FEBRUARY.part7: For as many as are led by the Spirit of God, they are the sons of God.  THOUGHT  embers of the same family may share some physical resemblances and hence be identified as belonging to that family. Drawn from across the ages, geography, history, ethnicity, culture, varying in outward form, social circumstances, with diverse gifts, faculties and endowments, the sons of God have hardly any external resemblance. Yet they have one resemblance inwardly - being led by the Spirit of God. The Bible gives us such godly examples - Joseph, the prime minister of the Egyptian empire; Mordecai the Jew, sitting despised at the king's gate; Solomon arrayed in all his glory; Lazarus clothed in rags and starving to death; Paul with his mighty intellect and Moses who was slow in speech. The local church is a microcosm of God's larger family. The minds and hearts of the sons of God, both young and old, from all walks of life, yield to the direction of God's Spirit to love and obey Him and seeking to please Him. They delight themselves in the Lord [Psalm 37:4], uniting in heart and spirit, in love and corporate worship. "And let us consider one another to provoke unto love and to good works: Not forsaking the assembling of ourselves together, as the manner of some is; but exhorting one another: and so much the more, as ye see the day approaching" [Hebrews 10:24-25]. Mindful of the Lord's commandment to His disciples in John 13:33-35, the sons of God will love each other even as they serve together in humility, esteeming others better than themselves so as to fulfil the great commission [Matthew 28:19-20] and looking eagerly forward to His return [Revelation 22:20]. But as many as received Him, to them gave He power to become the sons of God, even to them that believe on His name. - John 1:12

16 FEBRUARY.part2: The Spirit of Bondage Leads to Fear
16 FEBRUARY.part7: For ye have not received the spirit of bondage again to fear; but ye have received the Spirit of adoption, whereby we cry, Abba, Father.  THOUGHT  efore we were saved by the Lord Jesus, each of us was a slave of sin, controlled by its power and unable to break free. No matter how we denied it or claimed indifference, we were continually subject to fear because we were living under God's judgement. We were also under the bondage of the law, attempting to please God through good works or fulfilling the prescriptions of the law. Alas, we could never obey it perfectly, ever falling short of God's holy standards. We sought peace, comfort and joy in worldly pursuits and pleasures but found nothing lasting. Our lusts and desires were never satiated. The worship of other gods did not give us assurance of acceptance, freedom from sin's guilt or confidence that we will be worthy to enter heaven. Such was the hopeless state we were in, plagued by the fear of future punishment at the hands of a just, holy and righteous God, with nowhere to hide. We thank God that He is gracious and merciful to us. He looked down on us in love and delivered us from our sinful, wretched state. God saved us by the gift of salvation through His only begotten Son, our Lord Jesus, who died in our place. The blood of Christ shed on Calvary's cross washed away our sins so that we are justified and reconciled to God. Now, all fear of hellfire judgement is removed, and we have the blessed assurance of eternal life in heaven.  But God be thanked, that ye were the servants of sin, but ye have obeyed from the heart that form of doctrine which was delivered you. Being then made free from sin, ye became the servants of righteousness. - Romans 6:17-18

17 FEBRUARY.part2: The Spirit of Adoption Leads to Faith
17 FEBRUARY.part7: For ye have not received the spirit of bondage again to fear; but ye have received the Spirit of adoption, whereby we cry, Abba, Father.  THOUGHT  n the past, we were slaves to sin in rebellion against God. By nature, we were children of wrath and children of Satan [Ephesians 2:3, John 8:44]. When we were saved from our sins, we were adopted by into God's family, meaning our Heavenly Father admits us to the rights and privileges of His sons and daughters. We receive a new status and enter into a new relationship with Him. In the Old Testament, Jews regarded the name of Jehovah as too sacred to write or say. This led to a detached and impersonal relationship of reverence and fear of God. But in the earthly ministry of our Lord Jesus, He revealed a relationship with the Father that was intimate, close and personal. Jesus taught the disciples to pray, addressing God as "Father" [Matthew 6:9]. In the Garden of Gethsemane, Jesus prayed, "Abba, Father" [Mark 14:36]. Abba is the Aramaic term of endearment that small children used to address their fathers, indicating love and affection in the Son's relationship with God the Father. It reflects a joy and desire to commune with Him because of the inseparable spiritual bond that exists between the Father and His only begotten Son. Our Lord Jesus showed us we too can have a very personal and close relationship with God as His children. This relationship is characterised by God's love for us and the confidence that we can go to God freely and He will not turn us away. The assurance that He will hear all our petitions builds our faith in God that He who saved us at the first will save us to the uttermost.  To redeem them that were under the law, that we might receive the adoption of sons. And because ye are sons, God hath sent forth the Spirit of His Son into your hearts, crying, Abba, Father. - Galatians 4:5-6

18 FEBRUARY.part3: VERSE 16 take notice and we give God the praise and glory.
18 FEBRUARY.part7: The Spirit itself beareth witness with our spirit, that we are the children of God.  THOUGHT  he Holy Spirit works in many ways in us who are adopted sons and daughters of God. Firstly, the Holy Spirit convicts us of our sins and sanctifies us. We are transformed and made more Christ-like in holiness. We develop a hatred for sin and distaste for the ways of the world. We bear the fruit of the Spirit while the works of the flesh become increasingly less evident in our lives. This marked difference in behaviour causes others to take notice and we give God the praise and glory. Secondly, the Spirit fosters in us the desire to commune with God in prayer and read His Word. We long to know God's will and His commands to us, seeking to obey His will. The inspired Word of God written by men directed by the Holy Spirit testifies of the work of salvation that God has done in us. Thirdly, the Spirit illumines our minds and gives us spiritual understanding so we are not blind to the message contained in God's Word. We understand truths that cannot be understood without the Spirit's enlightenment. Peter's confession of Christ as God the Son was only possible because spiritual insight from God the Holy Spirit enabled him to recognise who Jesus really was [Matthew 16:1617]. Others who observed the same things of Jesus and heard His teaching could not make the same confession because of spiritual blindness. We thank God for giving us the Holy Spirit. It is the witness of His Spirit in our lives that gives us the great assurance that we are truly saved by God.  Hereby know we that we dwell in Him, and He in us, because He hath given us of His Spirit. - 1 John 4:13

God sends us trials to strengthen our faith, chastisement to correct us and grace to go through each day. Truly, the blessings of salvation in our Lord Jesus are more than we deserve.  Behold, what manner of love the Father hath bestowed upon us, that we should be called the sons of God: therefore the world knoweth us not, because it knew Him not. - 1 John 3:1

We are heirs of God, and since our Lord Jesus is God's only begotten Son and the firstfruit of the resurrection, we are also co-heirs with Christ for we share in His sufferings in this fallen world and in His resurrection to the next, and in God's grace, we will be like Him, enjoying glory in the future to come. And he said to them all, If any man will come after me, let him deny himself, and take up his cross daily, and follow me. - Luke 9:23

21 FEBRUARY.part7: And if children, then heirs; heirs of God, and joint-heirs with Christ; if so be that we suffer with him, that we may be also glorified together.  THOUGHT  t is interesting how Paul maps out the Christian path to glory - through the sufferings we must need go through in this world. In fact, we could even say Paul sees sufferings as an essential part of Christian life, a distinctive mark of God's children. Paul is not an armchair philosopher who thinks he has worked out the solutions to all the big questions of life. He is a realist - just like all Christians should be. The truth is many things that happen in this world are not within our control or understanding. Neither do we have answers to all things God allows to come our way. Committing ourselves wholly to God does not mean we need not face pain and suffering in the here and now. However, unlike people of the world, we do not become frustrated or even angry with man and God. Neither do we live a life of denial and disengagement from the world, becoming disillusioned and discouraged. THOUGHT  t the time of Adam's Fall in the Garden, all of creation was corrupted along with Adam and Eve, and it continues to be subject to the same futility we face as human beings.
