The Bible does not teach the annihilation of this planet, but rather its renovation and redemption. The Scriptures promise a new heaven and a new earth: a cosmic transformation whereby the work of redemption effected by Christ will not only bring renewal, sanctification and glorification to man, but also renewal, sanctification and glorification to our natural world, to our natural environment. In this verse, Paul specifies the content of the hope that he mentioned at the end of verse 20: the hope that creation would be set free from decay into the freedom of the glory of the children of God. When we look around at nature and marvel at its beauty and splendour, realize there will be a day when all of creation will shine even brighter in its brilliance, that truly glorious day of total eradication of the presence and consequence of sin in our lives. 7 MARCH.part7: For we know that the whole creation groaneth and travaileth in pain together until now.  THOUGHT  ust as we groan because of displeasure with regard to particular circumstances, creation groans because of her discontent with her present state. The language Paul uses is a graphic description of the suffering that is inflicted upon the earth. The earth is a place where there is much sorrow, and the sorrow that afflicts our lives is described here as a sorrow that impacts the whole creation and elicits groans from it. This image of groaning is linked with the idea of travail or birthing pains. Birthing pain depicts for us the intensity of groanings that so burden creation. But creation does not pine away without a prospect of remedy. Note that the groaning and pain which Paul speaks are like the pains of childbirth, a specific kind of intense pain. When the apostle speaks of creation groaning, it is like the painful pangs of an expectant mother during childbirth. Even though the created world is going through pain, it is not an agony that ends in termination or annihilation but an agony that culminates in the unspeakable joy of birth and new life, of renovation and redemption. Jesus makes this very application in John 16:20-22 whereupon the deliverance of a newborn child, the mother "remembereth no more the anguish". "Sing unto the LORD, O ye saints of his, and give thanks at the remembrance of his holiness. For his anger endureth but a moment; in his favour is life: weeping may endure for a night, but joy cometh in the morning." [Psalm 30:4-5]  Dear Lord, may I have the same anguish that all creation has in this present world, and not be so comfortable and attached to this place which is not my eternal home.

That final element of our salvation, the future consummation of the fullness of glory, is something we still have not experienced. Yet we have what Paul calls "the firstfruits of the Spirit". We do not simply have a promise of the future with no present participation in that future; but rather, we have a foretaste of the glory to come, by the newness of life we already experience in Christ through the Holy Spirit. But it is a taste which is co-mingled with an ongoing struggle against sin, mixed with a coat of suffering that still causes us, in spite of the joy of our salvation, to weep, to suffer, to hurt. The firstfruits of the Spirit is like a down payment, with the Divine promise that the full measure of the blessing will most certainly come. We still suffer from the effects and consequences of the Fall upon our mortal bodies. We know what it means to grow old; what it means to experience degeneration and decay; what it means to suffer the ravages of disease. But we anticipate a salvation that redeems both soul and body. The glory given to Christ was manifested in a glorified, resurrected human body, and His glory is the firstfruits of what we will experience. We too will inherit bodies that are incorruptible and immortal, not subject to pain, disease, suffering and death. We know these things will come to pass because God has promised them. To do so, one must travel to a poor country, throw away one's passport and give up any possibility of returning to the comfort of one's home. It is then they may perhaps come near to understanding poverty - to be poor is not to be materially deprived; rather it is the loss of hope that things will change. Hope is the strength and motivation of every Christian, yet our hope is not crossing our fingers and wishfully hoping for a better tomorrow. It is based on what we believe, which has withstood the test of time and proven true. Our hope centres on Christ and what He has done for us. Our hope lies in the faithful promises of God. Hebrews 11, the great chapter on faith, tells us the relationship between hope and faith - the basis and certainty of hope is our faith: "Now faith is the substance of things hoped for, the evidence of things not seen" [Hebrews 11:1] - faith in the just and loving God who gave us His Word. With the knowledge of God's love for us, we can then find strength to love others, and do it with much peace and joy. The pivotal role of hope in our salvation is thus clear: because of our faith, we have hope, and with that hope, we will find strength to live and love, waiting for that day when Christ will return - when all that we hope in and for becomes reality.  Now the God of hope fill you with all joy and peace in believing, that ye may abound in hope, through the power of the Holy Ghost. - Romans 15:13

11 MARCH.part7: But if we hope for that we see not, then do we with patience wait for it.  THOUGHT  aith, hope and waiting go hand in hand. We believe in what we hope for, and thus are willing to wait patiently for it to come to pass. Yet the Christian hope is not one of passive enduring, but proactive looking forward, waiting and serving Christ with good spirits in whatever vocation God has placed us. In the Lord's prayer, we pray for God's kingdom to come [Matthew 6:10] - when this present kingdom of grace will be replaced by His kingdom of glory. But from now till then, as we wait for the day of Christ, we should put on our best to shine for Him, in both the good times and the bad. Is life smooth sailing now? Thank and praise God for His blessings, for "every good gift and every perfect gift is from above, and cometh down from the Father of lights, with whom is no variableness, neither shadow of turning" [James 1:17]. Look for ways you can be a channel of blessing to others, testifying to them concerning the source of your material and spiritual abundance, a foretaste of a greater inheritance to come. Are you negotiating a bad patch in life now? Also thank and praise God for this opportunity to shine for Him in your trials. "But sanctify the Lord God in your hearts: and be ready always to give an answer to every man that asketh you a reason of the hope that is in you with meekness and fear: Having a good conscience; that, whereas they speak evil of you, as of evildoers, they may be ashamed that falsely accuse your good conversation in Christ" [1 Peter 3:15-16].  The LORD is good unto them that wait for Him, to the soul that seeketh Him. It is good that a man should both hope and quietly wait for the salvation of the LORD. - Lamentations 3:25-26.

12 MARCH.part7: Likewise the Spirit also helpeth our infirmities: for we know not what we should pray for as we ought: but the Spirit itself maketh intercession for us with groanings which cannot be uttered.  PRAYER  Likewise (after the same manner) the Spirit also helpeth our infirmities". Paul either links "likewise" to other references to the Holy Spirit in chapter 8 or he is linking it with the encouragement and hope of Romans 8:18-25. The word "infirmities" refers to the weakness to which we are subject and to problems and trials in this life. Our Lord is ever mindful of our need of Him, for He knows how weak and infirmed we are. The word "weakness" in the New Testament can be weakness owing to our limited human nature [Romans 6:19] or weakness owing to sickness [Luke 5:15] or weakness owing to adversity [2 Corinthians 12:9-10]. We are also bound by weakness within [Matthew 26:41; 2 Corinthians 12:5-10] and powerful enemies without [Ephesians 6:11-13]. The particular weakness apostle Paul cites that affects all aspects of our life is that we do not know what to pray in unusual circumstances and crises. For all these, our Lord Jesus does not give up on us but sends us the Holy Spirit to help us. He excites us to pray and assists us in prayer. The Greek word Paul uses for the Spirit's role in prayer is syn-anti-lambanetai, which means "always helping together". The word refers to someone coming alongside another to take part of a heavy load and helping to bear it. The word "helpeth" is only used twice in the New Testament. The other instance is in Luke 10:40, where Martha begs the assistance of Mary to help her in the work she is doing to share with her in serving. Let us always seek the Spirit to help with our infirmities. Father, I openly confess my weakness to You: I don't really know how to pray. Give me the right words at the right moment. Help me with the words that flow from my lips, until they truly become part of me.

13 MARCH.part7: Likewise the Spirit also helpeth our infirmities: for we know not what we should pray for as we ought: but the Spirit itself maketh intercession for us with groanings which cannot be uttered.  THOUGHT  We know not what we should pray for as we ought". This clause comprehends both the matter and the manner of our prayers; both what we should ask and how we should ask it. When James and John came to our Lord Jesus during His earthly ministry, they desired that they should sit the one on His right hand and the other on His left in His kingdom, but He said to them, "Ye know not what ye ask" [Matthew 20:22; Mark 10:38a]. They had not the right idea either of the nature of His kingdom, or the principles on which the honours of that kingdom are bestowed. "Ye ask and receive not," says James, "because ye ask amiss" [James 4:3]. Paul himself knew not what to pray for as he ought when he "besought the Lord thrice" that his great physical trouble ("the thorn in the flesh") be removed from him and was refused [2 Corinthians 12:8-9]. The Son of man Himself prayed, "saying, Father, if Thou be willing, remove this cup from Me: nevertheless not My will, but Thine, be done" [Luke 22:42], and learnt in experience that it was not possible. We often do not know how to pray as we should, but thankfully God does not leave us to ourselves. He has graciously given us the Holy Spirit to help us in our prayers. He is a partner in our prayers. Let us be thankful that we pray to a God who can discern the prayer within our prayers. The prayer that our Lord taught His disciples, known as the Lord's prayer, is a model to guide His followers concerning proper principles and goals of prayer [Matthew 6:9-13]. Ye have not chosen Me, but I have chosen you, and ordained you, that ye should go and bring forth fruit, and that your fruit should remain: that whatsoever ye shall ask of the Father in My name, He may give it you. - John 15:16

14 MARCH.part3: VERSE 26 word for groaning, stenagmos, refers to intense yet
14 MARCH.part7: Likewise the Spirit also helpeth our infirmities: for we know not what we should pray for as we ought: but the Spirit itself maketh intercession for us with groanings which cannot be uttered.  THOUGHT  omans 8:34 says that our Lord Jesus "is even at the right hand of God, who also maketh intercession for us". In 1 John 2:1, we read that He is our "advocate with the Father", and from Hebrews 7:25, we learn that He "ever liveth to make intercession". Paul here in Romans 8:26 speaks of a similar intercessory prayer by the Holy Spirit: "the Spirit itself maketh intercession for us with groanings which cannot be uttered." The Greek word for groaning, stenagmos, refers to intense yet inaudible sighing. Sometimes the struggles and sufferings of life become so heavy we just cannot bear them. At other times, temptations and troubles grip our hearts to such an extent that words are impossible. Emotions become too much for words. Every genuine believer knows what it is to be speechless before God and left groaning in the Spirit, like how Moses [Exodus 14:15] and Hannah [1 Samuel 1:13] prayed. Though the groanings "cannot be uttered", they are heard by God. They are understood and will be answered for the Spirit that is in us is the Spirit who "searcheth all things, yea, the deep things of God" [1 Corinthians 2:10], and He, therefore "maketh intercession for the saints according to the will of God" [v. 27b]. The Spirit interceding in us groans on our behalf, takes up our needs at the deepest emotional level and conveys our hurts and cares to the Father's throne, all in line with the will of God. This should encourage us to pour out our hearts before Him [Psalm 62:8].  Praying always with all prayer and supplication in the Spirit, and watching thereunto with all perseverance and supplication for all saints. - Ephesians 6:18

15 MARCH.part7: And he that searcheth the hearts knoweth what is the mind of the Spirit, because he maketh intercession for the saints according to the will of God.  THOUGHT  omans 8:27 gives us great assurance that we are not left to ourselves to cope with our sorrows, challenges, anxiety and pain. The Holy Spirit searches our hearts and minds. Even when we do not know the right words to pray, the Holy Spirit prays with and for us. And we can be assured that the Holy Spirit's prayers are according to God's will. As believers of Christ, we have the Holy Spirit who superintends and guards us in our prayers. We can take comfort He is always there with us and interceding for us before God. No matter the situation, the Holy Spirit knows what is ultimately best for us. This is evident from verse 28, which says, "And we know that all things work together for good to them that love God ... " We can trust that God will always do what is best and turn every circumstance for our own good, according to His purpose. We are also reminded in 1 Chronicles 28:9 to keep an intimate relationship with God, and to serve Him wholeheartedly with willing minds, for "the LORD searcheth all hearts, and understandeth all the imaginations of the thoughts". God knows our heart and our motivations for serving Him; the Spirit resides with those who have humble and contrite hearts rather than those who choose self-interests over God's. To truly love the Lord, we must know Him better by meditating on His law and precepts, and developing a personal relationship with Him. Blessed is the man who trusts in the Lord, who yields himself entirely to the guidance of the Holy Spirit. I the LORD search the heart, I try the reins, even to give every man according to his ways, and according to the fruit of his doings. - Jeremiah 17:10

16 MARCH.part2: According to the Will of God
16 MARCH.part7: And he that searcheth the hearts knoweth what is the mind of the Spirit, because he maketh intercession for the saints according to the will of God.  THOUGHT  ow do I know what is the will of God? How can I find God's will in me? How do I know I am praying in accordance with God's will? Fret not, for we are assured God has a perfect will for each of us, and the Holy Spirit is praying for us in accordance with His will. Ephesians 5:17 states that "wherefore be ye not unwise, but understanding what the will of the Lord is." We are urged by apostle Paul to seek God's will, to be more Christ-like and do good. As God's children, we grow into spiritual maturity through prayer, studying the Scriptures and obeying God's teachings. It is foolish to go against God's will by sinning and grieving the Holy Spirit that has been granted by the Lord to stay within us. Rather, we should pray for the guidance of the Holy Spirit to keep us from falling, restore our faith in the Lord and help us stay faithful, walking the narrow path with the Lord. Only with renewed minds, focusing on Christ rather than self, when we submit to and obey Him will God show us His will for our lives. When one is depressed, disappointed or sad, it may be difficult to pray and give thanks. Take heart - for in all things God works for our good if we love Him and are called according to His purpose. Thank God for His enabling power and strength, giving us confidence and joy to live day by day. We can rest assured that God's perfect love will see us through and make us stronger in Him.  O Lord my God, thank you for guiding and teaching me. Thank you for Your promise to walk daily with me. I pray that you open my heart to let Your word and truth turn my heart from sin and renew my mind in goodness and truthfulness. Amen.

17 MARCH.part3: VERSE 27 in terms of whether it 1s His hidden or His revealed
17 MARCH.part7: And he that searcheth the hearts knoweth what is the mind of the Spirit, because he maketh intercession for the saints according to the will of God.  THOUGHT  oday's verse tells us the importance of God's will to the child of God. Our Lord Jesus teaches us to pray for God's will to be done, and 1 John 5:14 assures us that if we pray and ask of God according to His will, He will hear our prayers. So, let us spend some time considering the will of God in today's meditation. Firstly, we need to understand the nature of God's will. Theologians often speak of God's will in terms of whether it is His hidden or His revealed will. It is easier to explain what His revealed will is: it is that which is revealed in the Scriptures. God, in His wisdom and providence, revealed all that He wants us to know in the Scriptures, meaning the Bible. Indeed, everything man can know about God: His person, His attributes, His redemption plan, and His revealed will, can be found in the Scriptures and we believe only in the Scriptures. That leaves the definition of the hidden will of God as that which God does not deem necessary for us to know, and not necessary for our salvation. Dear child of God, seeing that the will of God is to be found in the Scriptures alone, let us draw close to His will by studying His Word, because only then can we say that we are walking close to Him. God's Word is profitable for us, and in reading it we are grounded in the right doctrines, reproved and corrected when we sin, and instructed in righteous living.  All scripture is given by inspiration of God, and is profitable for doctrine, for reproof, for correction, for instruction in righteousness: That the man of God may be perfect, thoroughly furnished unto all good works. - 2 Timothy 3:16-17

18 MARCH.part7: And he that searcheth the hearts knoweth what is the mind of the Spirit, because he maketh intercession for the saints according to the will of God.  THOUGHT  esterday, we looked at how the Scriptures are the only reliable source of God's revealed will. Why does God reveal to us His will in the Scriptures? Again 2 Timothy 3:16-17 tells us that in reading and obeying the Scriptures, a godly man may be perfect and thoroughly equipped for all good works, namely for the work that God has called him to. Theologians often refer to God's revealed will as His moral will, because in obeying God's will, a man can live a morally upright and righteous life. Thus, the godly man becomes a witness for the Gospel and a light in a world of darkness. Our God is the Almighty God, and a loving God who cares for us, whom He created. He loved Adam and Eve, even though they disobeyed Him and were banished from Eden. God in His infinite love made it possible for fallen man to be reconciled to Him. He demonstrated His love when He called Abraham out of his comfortable life to journey to the Promised Land. And through Abraham's offspring, came the Jewish people whom God had specially chosen to be keepers of His Word. Finally, He showed His love through Jesus, a descendent of Abraham, who lived a perfect life and died a sacrificial death for the sins of all who believe in Him. Dear child of God, ultimately God's will is for all to come to repentance and believe in Him. And we who have believed, have the sacred duty to share this Gospel of good news to all who are lost in sin and darkness. Are you ready to do God's will here and now? The Lord is not slack concerning his promise, as some men count slackness; but is longsuffering to us-ward, not willing that any should perish, but that all should come to repentance. - 2 Peter 3:9

19 MARCH.part7: And we know that all things work together for good to them that love God, to them who are the called according to his purpose.  THOUGHT  e come now to perhaps the most comforting verse in the Bible for Christians. When we go through trials in life, grieve for the loss of loved ones, or undergo inexplicable suffering, this verse ministers to our souls and strengthens our hope in our sovereign and mighty God. Paul begins this verse with the words "and we know". He does not simply tell us that all things work together for our good; he says categorically "we know" it. In what sense do we know? Do we come to know from our experiences, or is it a fact that we can be certain of ? While the underlying Greek word supports both nuances of its meaning, Paul's emphasis is on the latter. This is something that we, all Christians, should know as a fact, regardless of our experiences because it is grounded in God's certain sovereignty which Paul elaborates in verses 29 and 30. All things work together for good to those who are called according to His purpose - that they should be conformed to the image of His Son and share in His glory. Because this is God's purpose for us who are called, we can be certain that He will work all things for our good and realize His purpose for us. We can rest in the security that God is in control. All things will come to pass as He has purposed it. And because God's sovereignty is certain, our hope is sure.  ...I have spoken it, I will also bring it to pass; I have purposed it, I will also do it. - Isaiah 46:11b

20 MARCH.part3: VERSE 28 He is the Lord over all creation. He created all
20 MARCH.part7: And we know that all things work together for good to them that love God, to them who are the called according to his purpose.  THOUGHT  ext, Paul tells us that all things work together for our good. The term "all things" is general. Paul does not specify what they include, but he would have in mind the sufferings of this present time [v. 18], tribulation, distress, persecution, famine, nakedness, peril, sword, and even death [v. 35-36]. But its scope is not limited to these. All that is in this life, even our sins, can be used by God for our good. God can work all things for our good because He is the Lord over all creation. He created all things, sustains all things, and rules over all things [Colossians 1:16-17; Hebrews 1:3]. As King of kings and Lord of lords, He has supreme power and authority over everything. There is nothing He does not know [Romans 11:33] and nothing He cannot control [Psalm 103:19]. His sovereignty is all-encompassing. But this does not mean He is the direct cause of everything that occurs. He is not the author of sin. Yet nothing can happen unless He allows it to happen. And everything that happens inevitably serves only to accomplish His purpose. As Christians, we have great comfort knowing that nothing escapes God's sovereign control. So, no matter what situations we find ourselves in, we can be sure they are happening in accordance with His plan and intention. Nothing is left to chance, and everything will work out exactly as He has purposed, for our good and not for evil, so that God may be glorified in all.  For of Him, and through Him, and to Him, are all things: to Whom be glory for ever. Amen. - Romans 11:36

21 MARCH.part7: And we know that all things work together for good to them that love God, to them who are the called according to his purpose.  THOUGHT  hy does God allow evil to exist in the world? Why does God allow bad things to happen? Why does God allow the innocent to suffer? In trying to answer all these questions, some may conclude that there is no God, or that there is a God, but He is inactive in the affairs of the world. But verse 28 tells us that neither is true. God exists. And not only has God created all things, but He is also actively at work, caring for His creation and directing all things for the supreme good of His people. The work of God's sovereign guidance and care for His creation is known as His providence. We do not always understand what God is doing, let alone welcome it. But we know that everything that God does is directed towards accomplishing His purpose for His people. Nothing can frustrate God's providence - not our sins or failures, not the jealousy or opposition of others, not circumstances or our own indifference. Where God permit sins and evil, they will invariably serve to accomplish His purpose. This is most gloriously displayed on the cross where, by God's set purpose and foreknowledge, the wickedness of men ultimately resulted in the completion of Christ's work of atonement and salvation for His people [Acts 2:23]. God is tirelessly working for the good of His people. He never sleeps. So, as God's beloved, we can rest in His all-seeing sovereignty and trust in the goodness of His providence.  My help cometh from the LORD, which made heaven and earth. He will not suffer thy foot to be moved: he that keepeth thee will not slumber. - Psalm 121:2-3

22 MARCH.part7: And we know that all things work together for good to them that love God, to them who are the called according to his purpose.  THOUGHT  omans 8:28 can be misunderstood because of how we define "good". We often pray for things we believe are good for us - a steady job, good health, success, happiness, etc. No one asks for sickness, suffering, persecution, or death. There is nothing good about them so how can such things be for our good? To understand this verse properly, we must be careful to define "good" on God's terms and not ours. Things that are "good" for us are not things that bring material wealth or health, or anything that the world seeks after. "Good" must be understood in relation to God's purpose for His people, which is "to be conformed to the image of His Son" and ultimately share in His glory [Romans 8:29-30]. In other words, things that are for our "good" are those that sanctify us and help us grow in Christlikeness, till we reach the final stage of our salvation in glorification. When seen in this light, we can indeed rejoice in sufferings and trials for they contribute to our "good" by refining our faith and strengthening our hope [Romans 1:3-5; James 1:2-4]. Admittedly, in times of pain and grief, it is hard for us to accept or see the need to suffer for our spiritual good. During such times, we must look beyond our circumstances and fix our eyes on our Almighty God, trusting in His goodness and allloving sovereignty, patiently waiting for Him in hope, knowing that ultimately everything will work out exactly as He has purposed, for our good and for His glory.  Being confident of this very thing, that he which hath begun a good work in you will perform it until the day of Jesus Christ. - Philippians 1:6

23 MARCH.part7: And we know that all things work together for good to them that love God, to them who are the called according to his purpose.  THOUGHT  omans 8:28 is a wonderful promise of God, but the promise is not for everyone. It is only for those who "love God" or more specifically, those who are "called according to his purpose." Both phrases refer to the same people - born-again Christians. Those who "love God" is simply an expression to describe God's people, people whose hearts have been regenerated and are inclined towards God. Those who are called are those who have been effectually summoned by God to enter into a relationship with Him. This calling is not an invitation to respond to the Gospel. It is a particular call by which the Holy Spirit regenerates and works saving grace in a sinner's heart. The foundation of God's calling is God's purpose. The underlying Greek word for "purpose", prothesis, refers to something which has been set forth in advance. This means that God has chosen or elected in advance who should receive His call and come into His saving grace. God elects "according to His purpose" before a person is born [Romans 9:11]. He does it freely, after the counsel of His own will [Ephesians 1:11]. His purpose is eternal, which means God has set forth from eternity whom He would call [Ephesians 3:11]. When understood correctly, God's purposeful sovereignty in salvation brings us much assurance. Our salvation is based on and upheld by God's eternal purpose, not by our will or ability to sustain in the faith. This should drive us to humble gratitude and greater love for our sovereign Creator who has shown us mercy.  So then it is not of him that willeth, nor of him that runneth, but of God that sheweth mercy. - Romans 9:16

24 MARCH.part7: For whom he did foreknow, he also did predestinate to be conformed to the image of his Son, that he might be the firstborn among many brethren.  THOUGHT  n Romans 8:29-30, we read what is sometimes called "the golden chain of salvation". There are essentially five interconnected rings in this chain and the first two are found in today's verse: God's foreknowledge and God's predestination, both of which happened long before time, or we can also say, outside time, in accordance with God's eternal counsel. To understand this, we need to realise that though God has chosen to work in time, He is not constrained by it. God's omniscience is such that He sees every event in time together as a whole, unlike finite beings like us who see events in chronological order. This will help us appreciate God's foreknowledge. Foreknowledge does not mean God knows ahead of time who will believe in Him and given that knowledge calls that person to salvation. Instead, it means God loves and chooses (elects) a person before he even knows God, and then in God's good time, He ordains and calls that person to accept Jesus Christ as his personal Saviour and Lord. This understanding is important because it tells us the biblical doctrine of God's sovereignty. We are created according to God's own good purpose - to believe in Him and become more and more like Christ His Son, our Lord. Note the pronoun in verse 29 is "whom" and not "what". God's foreknowledge is of the person rather than the things he will do, or the faith he will have. We are the objects of God's marvellous love. God knew us individually, by name. He knows everything we are going through, just as a good shepherd knows every one of his sheep and their condition. Before I formed thee in the belly I knew thee; and before thou camest forth out of the womb I sanctified thee, and I ordained thee a prophet unto the nations. - Jeremiah 1:5

25 MARCH.part3: VERSE 29 fatalism. We are not helpless creatures who cannot
25 MARCH.part7: For whom he did foreknow, he also did predestinate to be conformed to the image of his Son, that he might be the firstborn among many brethren.  THOUGHT  od's predestination goes hand in hand with His foreknowledge. God knows and loves us before we know Him (foreknowledge), and He chooses us to be His children (predestination). These two components in the "golden chain of salvation" are the basis for the next three: His calling us according to His time, our justification, and eventually, our glorification. Contrary to popular belief, predestination is not fatalism. We are not helpless creatures who cannot escape our destiny. We have a freewill. In God's good time, He changes our worldview and mindset so that we come to see things from His perspective, as Ezekiel 36:26 tells us, "A new heart also will I give you, and a new spirit will I put within you: and I will take away the stony heart out of your flesh, and I will give you an heart of flesh." With this receptive heart we will see and comprehend God's truth, and having seen, we cannot resist His grace because we perceive how life as God's child is much better than one who is dead in sin. This will cause us to freely choose Him. Why did God save some and not all? We dare not speculate on God's perfect will and define fairness according to our limited wisdom. What we must know, however, is that ultimately the reason for our salvation is God's glory and that even God's judgment of sin serves that same purpose. We instead thank God He has chosen to save a remnant (of which we are part) who believe and pray we will be God's means to spread the Gospel to the people around us.  According as he hath chosen us in him before the foundation of the world, that we should be holy and without blame before him in love: Having predestinated us unto the adoption of children by Jesus Christ to himself, according to the good pleasure of his will. - Ephesians 1:4-5

26 MARCH.part2: Conformity to the Image of Christ
26 MARCH.part7: For whom he did foreknow, he also did predestinate to be conformed to the image of his Son, that he might be the firstborn among many brethren.  THOUGHT  hildren of God are to conform to our Lord's image in our sufferings. Our Lord came to this world to suffer for the sake of the Gospel. The Son of God "made Himself of no reputation, and took upon Him the form of a servant, and was made in the likeness of men: And being found in fashion as a man, He humbled Himself, and became obedient unto death, even the death of the cross" [Philippians 2:7-8]. This is indeed the mind of our Lord Jesus [Philippians 2:5], and we should be like Him, serving others with humility and sacrificial love. We are made to conform to His image in our holiness. As we deal with challenges in life each day, we remember God's grace in our sanctification: "That ye put off concerning the former conversation the old man, which is corrupt according to the deceitful lusts; And be renewed in the spirit of your mind; And that ye put on the new man, which after God is created in righteousness and true holiness" [Ephesians 4:22-24], dying to sin and living for our Lord. We will be conformed to the image of Jesus in our eventual glory. Time is moving toward that coming day when we will see our Lord face to face, and that day of consummation will mark the transitional point in our path to glory when we will be transformed and put on a glorified body and spirit: "But we all, with open face beholding as in a glass the glory of the Lord, are changed into the same image from glory to glory, even as by the Spirit of the Lord" [2 Corinthians 3:18].  For which cause we faint not; but though our outward man perish, yet the inward man is renewed day by day. - 2 Corinthians 4:16

27 MARCH.part3: VERSE 29 which cannot be touched with the feeling of our
27 MARCH.part7: For whom he did foreknow, he also did predestinate to be conformed to the image of his Son, that he might be the firstborn among many brethren.  THOUGHT  ur Lord Jesus is the firstborn in the way He walks before us. Living a life on this earth, He endured what we are going through each day, yet He sinned not, but fulfilled all righteousness required in God's standards. "Seeing then that we have a great high priest, that is passed into the heavens, Jesus the Son of God, let us hold fast our profession. For we have not an high priest which cannot be touched with the feeling of our infirmities; but was in all points tempted like as we are, yet without sin" [Hebrews 4:14-15]. And He is the head of the body, the church: who is the beginning, the firstborn from the dead; that in all things He might have the preeminence" [Colossians 1:17-18]. Our Lord Jesus should be the centre of our lives and we should acknowledge Him in all our ways, putting Him first in the choices we make. Our Lord is the firstborn in that like Him who died and resurrected again to eternal glory, our corruptible bodies will likewise rise again and put on incorruption in our resurrection glory. "But now is Christ risen from the dead, and become the firstfruits of them that slept. For since by man came death, by man came also the resurrection of the dead. For as in Adam all die, even so in Christ shall all be made alive. But every man in his own order: Christ the firstfruits; afterward they that are Christ's at his coming" [1 Corinthians 15:20-23]. THOUGHT  rdo salutis is Latin for "order of salvation". It focuses on the acts of God and the response of the individual in salvation. The ordo salutis spells out in verses 29-30 is foreknowledge, predestination, followed by calling, justification and glorification. It speaks of a way of organizing all the events of redemption in their consecutive order as they show up in an individual's life, by which he is joined to Christ by the Holy Spirit. The entire process is the work of God in Christ and by grace alone. It is a unifying work of God to bring us into union with Christ. It enables us to see clearly that it is God who saves, freeing us from the sinful tendency to take some credit for our salvation. As you continue to battle sin in your life, your ongoing sin is not proof that your salvation never happened. But it is a reminder you must continue looking to Christ, eagerly awaiting the day when your salvation will inevitably reach its completion. Do you see Jesus as more to be desired than anything else, and sufficient to save you from your sin? Let us pray for one another, that in every way Christ will be exalted through our conformity to Him, and we might enjoy the assurance that because of our election and predestination, everything will work together for our good. "But as many as received Him, to them gave He power to become the sons of God, even to them that believe on His name" [John 1:12]. Receive Him!  God sovereignly ordains each part of the ordo salutis in a person's salvation.

THOUGHT  he effectual call is understood as God's sovereign drawing of a sinner to salvation. What is it that God does when He intervenes in a person's life to bring him to faith? Is it God alone who changes the heart of the sinner, or does this change of heart rest also on the willingness of the sinner? The Lord Jesus said, "No man can come to Me, except the Father which hath sent Me draw him" [John 6:44]. While God calls all men externally, He only calls His own internally. Those who respond to the external call are those who have been called internally by God and given new birth. Then they respond in faith to the external call. The inward call is irresistible, not in the sense that you do not have the power to resist it, but your resistance cannot overcome it. God's effectual call effects what He intends it to do; namely, to bring us to saving faith. It reminds us that what God begins, in terms of the order of salvation, He always completes. For those who are externally called but reject the Gospel, all things will not be working together for their good. Every believer has also a call to service. Many have been gifted to serve in the church. They must sense an internal call, and this call must be confirmed by an external call from the church. God's call is a call to serve Him. May God's calling to you influence how you live and work at your calling.  Distinguish between the external call of the Gospel and the internal call of the Holy Spirit.

30 MARCH.part7: Moreover whom he did predestinate, them he also called: and whom he called, them he also justified: and whom he justified, them he also glorified.  THOUGHT  e, who can hardly predict what will happen in a year, a week, a day or even an hour, cannot imagine how far ahead God has been planning. God's plan began in eternity past and will come to fruition in eternity future. Unlike our plans, God's plan is certain, detailed and wisely drafted, and nothing can arise to upset it. For God, no alternative plan is necessary. Paul tells us God's plan from eternity past is for those He has predestinated and called to be justified. Being justified means to be declared righteous in God's sight. God purposed that we would be declared righteous not by our own efforts but through the sacrifice of Christ at the cross for us [Romans 3:24-25]. God purposed that in His time, those He called would be justified by Christ paying the penalty for their sins, and those who were sinners and lawbreakers would no longer have any penalty to pay. With God declaring us righteous, we no longer have to suffer the penalty for sin which is death. Not only are we acquitted, but we are also restored to favour with God. And not only restored but also declared to be co-heirs with Christ and friends of God [Romans 8:17; James 2:23]. God did not simply overlook our sins and write them off which would be at odds with His attributes of holiness and justice. Someone else took the penalty of our sin so we can stand before God, and call Him our Father and Friend. In God's plan, His sinless Son died for our sins, the just for the unjust, that He might bring us to God [1 Peter 3:18]. How are we living our lives knowing that God Himself died for us to free us from the death penalty of sin?

THOUGHT  O wretched man that I am! who shall deliver me from the body of this death?" [Romans 7:24]. As a messenger of God's perfect plan, Paul himself was only too aware how sin continues to plague every believer. Justification is God's acceptance of sinners but does not mean that we become perfect and sinless, living happily ever after. Instead, we presently see God dimly and imperfectly as if through a blurry mirror. Only in the future will we see Him face to face [1 Corinthians 13:12]. Glorification awaits us. It is God's final removal of sin from the life of the saved [v. 18]. When our Lord Jesus comes again, the saved will be transformed in an instant into perfect beings - we shall be changed in the twinkling of an eye [1 Corinthians 15:51]. One day, we will be glorified and be like Jesus. One day, sin will no longer trouble us, and we will enjoy the complete fulness and eternal favour of God's presence. Until then, we watch and wait for our Lord's return. Until then, we do not sit and snooze, for if we do we will be found unprepared when the bridegroom arrives [Matthew 25:1-13]. Until then, we diligently put to death the sins in us [v. 13] through meditation on God's Word, persevering obedience, faithful service, fervent prayer and fellowship with believers, and we behold His glory, being transformed into His image from glory to glory [2 Corinthians 3:18].
